087812249D8445888E4B33743B07E2F0.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

E7FDBCC3BCEE41E29BCEFB0C9ADC617C.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

955959332F2E4C0C96970C955BCE7E98.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

16B91F22B04D43C5A92A92388C24900B.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

A1135DDA78CB4F5EB45900AE14C7956C.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry.

732CDC561A5547899DF730A1442BA734.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals.

C7EB89634A5C426185EAA20691DC6A64.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety and networking observed during the work placement.

01ABCBCE2D664611B571C5C38132CD96.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

E78C01BE30AA40F29C6928EC68348F79.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

C4BD7C8692BA497EAE82EF6CA18A9F4F.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

D69E3466AB764014A9205D6CC9F9A504.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview.

BC3C6B941CBE434884B60864FE2C0777.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

6C52AEBE056840B6A9FF67F3C875F6A4.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

FE2CC54DA0B944778C8DBDC5CD5DA4B0.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours? Who is my supervisor? What should I wear? When will I be provided with safety training? What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement? Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance? What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided? What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace? How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative? Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow? Who is the first aid person? Where are safety notices posted? What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

5449901EA5464EB38799C89E9FBA081C.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

CC4FD7E9DCC145F6A351862B1C702A85.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

C3879FA437FC4B32852DB7E77D72BC5C.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement.

32359F725DC4401D971291CC7B08A692.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations.

7E2C877968D847A59FA2683927FBBFB1.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

9DBA5A8B6D64461295781FAA9AE36012.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

DF5EE41635854A53828D600A79A0C933.description: Reflect on personal commitment to working safely at all times.

D863E776FA35425EBDB105A3526D8DE6.description: Develop a list of rules for workplace safety that apply to all regardless of the workplace; sample rules include: Safety in the workplace is a personal and shared responsibility. Dress appropriately and wear personal protective equipment when required. Know emergency evacuation plans and procedures. Keep work areas neat and tidy. Know and follow workplace rules and procedures for working safety. Know personal or individual risks in the workplace and strategies to manage them. Know the procedure for reporting workplace accidents or safety incidents.

764035F4F3504018A71B63EDBBD3918C.description: Analyze a variety of given scenarios pertaining to the tourism sector to identify potential hazards and safety risks and recommend strategies for preventing workplace injuries.

C1D46F335FE54C8AA81C231EF8121819.description: Research statistics related to injuries that are common in each of the five industries (i.e., food and beverage, accommodation, recreation and entertainment, transportation, and travel services) in Saskatchewan and Canada.

67A05F2AB1DA48CCBA78D4735D608AFA.description: Develop strategies to mitigate risks identified for each of the five industries.

C448812442844499BFA59B6E67D3A33A.description: Discuss risk mitigation and its purpose.

8224B956817B45FC96448DB24199ECA7.description: Identify potential safety hazards and risks in each of the five tourism industries. Examples may include: exposure to cleaning products and other chemicals; musculoskeletal injuries from standing for long hours; slips, trips or falls; and burns from dishes, meals or drinks that are hot (food and beverage); ergonomic hazards (e.g., from bending, pushing carts and making beds); slips, trips and falls; respiratory, dermal and carcinogenic hazards from chemicals in cleaning products (accommodation); lifting and handling heavy loads; working at heights; extreme temperatures; exposure to chemicals in liquids such as paints, solvents, cleaners and bleach; and working alone (recreation and entertainment); distracted driving; failure to safety check vehicles; and driver fatigue (transportation); and, working alone in the office; excessive computer use; improper ergonomics (travel services)

58230EBD22BF43F68450C9F4C4E2FD86.description: Research employer, supervisor and employee responsibilities pertaining to occupational health and safety standards in the workplace as required by Saskatchewan law.

0247038689E547D5A672BA74722BB292.description: Discuss the importance to self and others (e.g., customers, colleagues, employer, family and friends) of working safely at all times.

BB9E754303A94C58B7ECEA6F5B773770.description: Examine strategies for ensuring safety in the tourism workplace.

55296BDCFB04460EB71CB3305639D3C3.description: Identify the skills, attitudes and behaviours necessary for retaining a job.

0D2254FC478D456F97FBA66BF0580A3A.description: Discuss the importance of follow-up and describe steps that can be taken to properly follow up after a job interview.

DB01C39B91FA49239797414F69E68701.description: Prepare for a job interview by: researching the potential employer/organization; reflecting on personal suitability for the available position; developing a list of, and answers for, questions commonly asked during an interview; developing a list of questions to ask the interviewer; and, listing what to do and what not to do during a job interview.

FC7ADE5399844437B45E12FB0C3572D7.description: Develop or modify personal career artifacts (e.g., documents such as a cover letter and resume) to suit the needs of a job application for a specific job in the tourism sector.

8BCB8C34D3EF4793B94C344BD8300471.description: Discuss the role of networking in supporting a successful job search.

7FA0B06CE1EB45E781A3804C9725851C.description: Research sources of employment/job postings for positions in tourism locally, provincially, nationally and globally.

85F08CCD8CB04F408C09DD9DB4DCB9CB.description: Explore skills, tools and strategies that support the job search process for employment in the tourism sector.

165076BC9524456AAF5DB7108974AEE9.description: Communicate research findings through a creative means such as a display, brochure, video, digital presentation, website or oral presentation.

96EA523DA8C54CC3A0047BA516AA53B6.description: Reflect upon personal suitability or non-suitability for specific tourism- related occupations considering criteria such as: initial and continuing educational and training requirements;duties and skills required for the occupation; work environment, including typical hours and shift work and typical locations; current wages received in Saskatchewan and how these compare to current wages in other regions of Canada; physical, mental and emotional stresses related to the occupation; workplace hazards and safety considerations; other occupations with which they interact; apprenticeship and/or certifications available and/or required in Saskatchewan; and, emerging and future trends in the industry.

C9AC6FB5900B486E9D79D1781DD5E670.description: Research which tourism-related occupations are facing shortages and which are oversubscribed locally, regionally and/or provincially.

CB2BE344610943029A85581ED49A88E1.description: Debunk common myths related to tourism jobs, such as: tourism jobs are found only in hotels, airlines and travel agencies; tourism jobs pay minimum wage; and, tourism jobs are available only in the summer.

33F5787D72684C2CA4D596DE15894A90.description: List personal interests, skills, abilities and traits that may lead to a career in the tourism sector.

E652964C624B4A10B7255D04A4F47FA9.description: Examine the roles, responsibilities, educational qualifications and personal and professional qualities common to people involved in tourism-related occupations.

D74CFF5E643A467C8CDF2A6588C640F9.description: Investigate careers in the tourism sector.

0A7C16A8C62E492D96B4F8BB57CB4684.description: Reflect on the role that entrepreneurs play in the tourism sector within the community and province.

6E8FBDDD6D7D4FCA8EE6517FA9BEC212.description: Discuss the rewards and challenges of being an entrepreneur.

BC788EA0C17F4FD69EA6BDD62CB2DF9B.description: Describe the steps of the entrepreneurial process, including: developing skills that may contribute to entrepreneurial success; identifying needs, wants or problems that need to be solved; examining opportunities to meet needs and wants and to solve problems; generating ideas to satisfy the opportunities; assessing the opportunities and ideas; using all available sources and resources to evaluate opportunities and ideas; planning, preparing and executing the venture; and, reflecting on the successes and challenges associated with the venture.

68BDAA60861148D88A21EDE6965997A8.description: List examples of entrepreneurial ventures in tourism found within the community and surrounding area or within Saskatchewan.

A1640030C0C042EA8560A43D52E7E3CE.description: Assess the importance of entrepreneurship to the tourism sector.

ED29BB1F296B4872A40658FFF761FE39.description: Create and present a travel promotion package for a destination outside of Canada including information that references: all five industries (i.e., food and beverage, accommodation, recreation and entertainment, transportation, and travel services); impacts on social, environmental, cultural and economic sustainability; considerations for personal safety; and, other pertinent information (e.g., currency, time zone, availability of basic items and requirements for travel documents).

1691B882A53D4FEE84B2BE8D1BEAB537.description: Assess the historical and cultural contributions of the area’s Indigenous peoples.

FB5E5F2C0A1B4ABA846AD4A45D030AC5.description: Research answers to questions related to the geography of the community or area, such as: location - Where is it (e.g., absolute location, referencing latitude and longitude and relative location, referencing other locations)? Why is it there?, place – What is it like there, considering both physical and human characteristics?, human/environment interaction – What is the relationship between humans and the environment? How has the landscape been shaped by humans? movement – What examples of movement of people, goods or ideas are present? Has immigration impacted the area? What are the modes of transportation and transportation routes? region – In what region is it located, and how is it similar or dissimilar to other regions?

BDD7EA23F94F4FDB92E5936AD4502B2F.description: Create a travel promotion package for a global destination outside Canada.

23AE219DF888417D94292525018276C5.description: Project F – Travel Destinations – The World (Optional)

A08E24E536BF47549E46627A69804E11.description: Reflect on personal contributions to and personal growth resulting from developing and executing the venture plan.

509D97937D454278984F04AAF7A75309.description: Reflect on the success and challenges of the venture based upon pre- determined criteria for success.

520190956A654D8D86EA9886D64EF1DA.description: Monitor the execution of the business plan and make adjustments, as required, throughout the process.

B473AFD00A19471E91A40A6EC3069FBC.description: Analyze the pros and cons of various opportunities to determine the best option(s) for a class or group project.

409C75C9FD8347B5839B47C873086D60.description: Identify potential tourism-related business opportunities that could function within the school or community.

C97F51386F924AD2AB2FE41E1E1F72F5.description: Plan, organize, facilitate and evaluate a tourism venture in the school or community.

120A579B53F846A981809860CD0ADDCC.description: Examine common sections of a business plan such as: Executive Summary; Business Description; Vision, Mission and Goals; Market Research and Analysis; Marketing Strategy; Operations Plan; Ownership and Management; and, Financial Plan.

7D9C7B52B70442ECA9ADDB5AC0341E36.description: Brainstorm a list of questions that are generally answered through the development of a business plan.

FEADA56BDF1C4E9DBEC1EFB8CC5489B0.description: Discuss the purpose of a business plan.

BA240053041844178DC3970062801000.description: Reflect on the statement, ‘Failing to plan is planning to fail.’ which is attributed to Benjamin Franklin.

B9E87C60AD4848BDB6A27C2ECDE7DF80.description: Discuss the concept of market research and why it is important (e.g., informs decisions about the viability of a proposed business idea) for the success of any entrepreneurial venture.

BEADF0A86184406BB7FFA602FC7FC5F0.description: Examine the process for developing a business plan.

67217B3511E2481A954367AC98FA944B.description: Research Saskatchewan’s tourism brand and suggest how businesses in the tourism sector have leveraged, or could leverage, that brand for mutual benefit.

CB393B4A6A274B37BA7F411B4DF8EF46.description: Discuss the relationship between branding and marketing and the importance of a strong brand for business success in the tourism sector.

42CC59A6AD7C463098A66D1D31CEB03A.description: Research the advantages (e.g., building customer recognition and loyalty, enhanced credibility, attracting customers who share the same values and developing an emotional connection with customers) and disadvantages (e.g., costs to develop and the potential difficulty in changing perceptions of the brand in the future) of branding.

9A986C9AF4204F80A2537A8875BEF244.description: Brainstorm examples of branding in the tourism sector (e.g., Moose Jaw as “Canada’s Most Notorious City,” Paris as the “City of Love,” Walt Disney’s Mickey Mouse ears, Las Vegas as the “Entertainment Capital of the World” and WestJet’s “Love Where You’re Going” platform).

69DBC4DFDCFD49F1A5AD6C9C1F5E4861.description: Analyze the importance of branding in the tourism sector.

E12D807E95364316B4913ADCFC24D028.description: Propose effective marketing strategies for a variety of tourism businesses intended for a variety of target audiences.

14C53726FEEF4223A55E6BE14D442120.description: Discuss how a tourism business can determine whether or not its marketing campaign has been successful.

F92D3108EC68439AA78C2CA4A5C8FC12.description: Research criteria such as cost, frequency and potential customer reach for selecting the most effective way to market a tourism business.

5A16951735AF47F8859112B9AC18644D.description: Brainstorm the advantages and disadvantages of each type of media for tourism marketing.

5F631E4F23C94C649083B0D79979007C.description: List a variety of media (e.g., mass media such as television and radio, outdoor advertising such as billboards and transit, print media such as newspapers and tourism information, and websites and social media) in which products/businesses can be marketed.

268A76FF93834D8E9F0A3802E8B3D241.description: Examine the impact of trends in tourism marketing.

A124E198DB694D87A0389F67B08B0C6F.description: Role-play situations that demonstrate the successful and unsuccessful application of service recovery skills in dealing with situations one has encountered or witnessed as a customer or service provider, or for fictitious scenarios (e.g., hotel guest is unhappy with an unclean room, guest reservation is lost or customer’s credit card is declined).

A0267C4E32F7400BA1B9150555AE3DFE.description: Outline the five steps in the service recovery cycle, including: anticipating customer needs; acknowledging their feelings; apologizing and owning the responsibility; offering alternatives; and, making amends.

D0362815232C43C9AC2FAD5D6A6C6E4F.description: Propose challenges (e.g., having to service multiple customers at the same time, being time-pressed to provide a response while being unsure of the response, facing an irate customer, having no solution to a customer’s problem, not being able to give a bigger discount and dealing with a service outage or crisis situation) that service professionals may face on the job.

4D02F40E0C3B4504B1A8927A87FEC2B0.description: Examine the concept of service recovery and its importance for business success.

430BD8F6C00D419689D696B86C7F2853.description: Assess problem- solving skills required for effective customer service recovery.

72C5E1F145C44E5085496850DF053B08.description: Discuss the importance of a risk mitigation plan including communication strategies to ensure the safety and security of both employees and patrons in response to unforeseen events (e.g., customer experiencing an allergic reaction, natural disaster or security threat).

B67F225885D140D899278D35BE3AC059.description: Discuss the relationship among the menu, type of restaurant and ambience for determining how to set a table in a particular venue.

EF513E0C5C6A4C659B1B05DEF130F179.description: Analyze differences between the North American place setting and a variety of international table settings such as Moroccan, French, Japanese and Mexican.

82CCC450FBFB4083A39421E28D321E50.description: Demonstrate setting a dinner table using the North American place setting arrangement.

D11050EF3A5B414F85B5CFCA4A3A791E.description: Role-play scenarios for providing good table service (e.g., greeting/seating customers, taking reservations, pouring water, taking customer orders, serving courses and presenting the bill) and bussing tables (e.g., changing tablecloths, clearing the table, loading a bus pan/trays and carrying a bus pan).

DB7173C4119E4EAF857D2135D44D7FBA.description: Discuss the importance of safety, good communication between front-of- house and back-of-house staff and interpersonal skills for workers in the food and beverage industry.

DCDFFB2E471A4178B552A0B3DED109FC.description: Differentiate between front-of-house (e.g., maître d’, waiter, greeter, host, bartender, busser, food runner and cashier) and back-of-house (e.g., chef, sous chef, prep cook, line cook, dishwasher and kitchen crew) positions within a food and beverage business and describe their respective roles.

E4B7D4BA17DC47C1AE68F610FE5D3957.description: Research ways that the food and beverage industry can accommodate customers with diverse backgrounds (e.g., cultural, social and demographic) and with diverse needs (e.g., accessibility, communication and mobility).

E1337225081D445DA96C1228985A04E5.description: Reflect on what it means to provide quality customer service within the food and beverage industry.

C634D45ED6C24D429BCB3EBD355AA2B7.description: Analyze elements of quality customer service within the food and beverage industry.

73748C2E70AC414E8FCC49FCF9293A73.description: Summarize potential positive and negative impacts on tourism and the local community when a location attains World Heritage Site designation.

EBE9E6D8D7E448E49694CD5DF7B6FD99.description: List examples of United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) World Heritage Sites found within Canada and other parts of the world.

6D5698D531D4437DB6AC5A2B7694A88C.description: Examine the work of organizations such as the United Nations World Tourism Organization that promote responsible, sustainable and accessible tourism.

A4BCFF4AC82744399BFC39691698F6AD.description: Conduct an inquiry into the reasons why tourism is a major industry or on the rise in specific countries and the factors that have contributed to its prominence and growth.

702E8B4E71F5494D92E636D04B452DD1.description: Identify countries where tourism is a major industry or is on the rise.

0848568CB4F14352B70FCC6965100509.description: Interpret statistics and facts related to global tourism, such as: economic impact; the number of jobs created by the industry; the number of visits to and within various regions of the world; and, annual spending on travel.

40FF97EA73ED434892F984D6BFC22C3F.description: Investigate the attitudes and habits of Saskatchewanians and Canadians pertaining to global tourism.

BC5E2E43B6724573807FFDB732D85F12.description: Identify trends (e.g., sharing economy, sustainability, eco tourism, business/leisure travel, robots and automation, artificial intelligence and virtual reality) that may impact global tourism.

08D141C508294349864FB4553D349BFE.description: Discuss the impact of the tourism sector on the global economy.

4F418E4DBB554B839F93F7BEEB949FBB.description: Research the evolution of global tourism.

9BDB67183D7344E28BC943A11BFA60C3.description: Discuss what is meant by the term global tourism.

57A8F0A7CF944B7D8C5F4F2522A250CB.description: Examine the role and impact of global tourism.
